33. A Lake Model of Employment

33.1Outline¶

In addition to what’s in Anaconda, this lecture will need the following libraries:

import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

33.2The Lake model¶

This model is sometimes called the lake model because there are two pools of workers:

  1. those who are currently employed.

  2. those who are currently unemployed but are seeking employment.

The “flows” between the two lakes are as follows:

  1. workers exit the labor market at rate ddd.

  2. new workers enter the labor market at rate bbb.

  3. employed workers separate from their jobs at rate α\alphaα.

  4. unemployed workers find jobs at rate λ\lambdaλ.

The graph below illustrates the lake model.

33.3Dynamics¶

Let ete_tet​ and utu_tut​ be the number of employed and unemployed workers at time ttt respectively.

The total population of workers is nt=et+utn_t = e_t + u_tnt​=et​+ut​.

The number of unemployed and employed workers thus evolves according to:

ut+1=(1−d)(1−λ)ut+α(1−d)et+bnt=((1−d)(1−λ)+b)ut+(α(1−d)+b)etet+1=(1−d)λut+(1−α)(1−d)et\begin{aligned} u_{t+1} &= (1-d)(1-\lambda)u_t + \alpha(1-d)e_t + bn_t \\ &= ((1-d)(1-\lambda) + b)u_t + (\alpha(1-d) + b)e_t \\ e_{t+1} &= (1-d)\lambda u_t + (1 - \alpha)(1-d)e_t \end{aligned}ut+1​et+1​​=(1−d)(1−λ)ut​+α(1−d)et​+bnt​=((1−d)(1−λ)+b)ut​+(α(1−d)+b)et​=(1−d)λut​+(1−α)(1−d)et​​
(1)

We can arrange (1) as a linear system of equations in matrix form xt+1=Axtx_{t+1} = Ax_txt+1​=Axt​ where

xt+1=[ut+1et+1]A=[(1−d)(1−λ)+bα(1−d)+b(1−d)λ(1−α)(1−d)]andxt=[utet].x_{t+1} = \begin{bmatrix} u_{t+1} \\ e_{t+1} \end{bmatrix} \quad A = \begin{bmatrix} (1-d)(1-\lambda) + b & \alpha(1-d) + b \\ (1-d)\lambda & (1 - \alpha)(1-d) \end{bmatrix} \quad \text{and} \quad x_t = \begin{bmatrix} u_t \\ e_t \end{bmatrix}.xt+1​=[ut+1​et+1​​]A=[(1−d)(1−λ)+b(1−d)λ​α(1−d)+b(1−α)(1−d)​]andxt​=[ut​et​​].
(2)

Suppose at t=0t=0t=0 we have x0=[u0e0]⊤x_0 = \begin{bmatrix} u_0 & e_0 \end{bmatrix}^\topx0​=[u0​​e0​​]⊤.

Then, x1=Ax0x_1=Ax_0x1​=Ax0​, x2=Ax1=A2x0x_2=Ax_1=A^2x_0x2​=Ax1​=A2x0​ and thus xt=Atx0x_t = A^tx_0xt​=Atx0​.

Thus the long-run outcomes of this system may depend on the initial condition x0x_0x0​ and the matrix AAA.

We are interested in how utu_tut​ and ete_tet​ evolve over time.

What long-run unemployment rate and employment rate should we expect?

Do long-run outcomes depend on the initial values (u0,eo)(u_0, e_o)(u0​,eo​)?

33.3.1Visualising the long-run outcomes¶

Let us first plot the time series of unemployment utu_tut​, employment ete_tet​, and labor force ntn_tnt​.

class LakeModel:
    """
    Solves the lake model and computes dynamics of the unemployment stocks and
    rates.

    Parameters:
    ------------
    λ : scalar
        The job finding rate for currently unemployed workers
    α : scalar
        The dismissal rate for currently employed workers
    b : scalar
        Entry rate into the labor force
    d : scalar
        Exit rate from the labor force

    """
    def __init__(self, λ=0.1, α=0.013, b=0.0124, d=0.00822):
        self.λ, self.α, self.b, self.d = λ, α, b, d

        λ, α, b, d = self.λ, self.α, self.b, self.d
        self.g = b - d
        g = self.g

        self.A = np.array([[(1-d)*(1-λ) + b,   α*(1-d) + b],
                           [        (1-d)*λ,   (1-α)*(1-d)]])


        self.ū = (1 + g - (1 - d) * (1 - α)) / (1 + g - (1 - d) * (1 - α) + (1 - d) * λ)
        self.ē = 1 - self.ū


    def simulate_path(self, x0, T=1000):
        """
        Simulates the sequence of employment and unemployment

        Parameters
        ----------
        x0 : array
            Contains initial values (u0,e0)
        T : int
            Number of periods to simulate

        Returns
        ----------
        x : iterator
            Contains sequence of employment and unemployment rates

        """
        x0 = np.atleast_1d(x0)  # Recast as array just in case
        x_ts= np.zeros((2, T))
        x_ts[:, 0] = x0
        for t in range(1, T):
            x_ts[:, t] = self.A @ x_ts[:, t-1]
        return x_ts
lm = LakeModel()
e_0 = 0.92          # Initial employment
u_0 = 1 - e_0       # Initial unemployment, given initial n_0 = 1

lm = LakeModel()
T = 100         # Simulation length

x_0 = (u_0, e_0)
x_path = lm.simulate_path(x_0, T)

fig, axes = plt.subplots(3, 1, figsize=(10, 8))


axes[0].plot(x_path[0, :], lw=2)
axes[0].set_title('Unemployment')

axes[1].plot(x_path[1, :], lw=2)
axes[1].set_title('Employment')

axes[2].plot(x_path.sum(0), lw=2)
axes[2].set_title('Labor force')

for ax in axes:
    ax.grid()

plt.tight_layout()
plt.show()

Not surprisingly, we observe that labor force ntn_tnt​ increases at a constant rate.

This coincides with the fact there is only one inflow source (new entrants pool) to unemployment and employment pools.

The inflow and outflow of labor market system is determined by constant exit rate and entry rate of labor market in the long run.

In detail, let 1=[1,1]⊤\mathbb{1}=[1, 1]^\top1=[1,1]⊤ be a vector of ones.

Observe that

nt+1=ut+1+et+1=1⊤xt+1=1⊤Axt=(1+b−d)(ut+et)=(1+b−d)nt.\begin{aligned} n_{t+1} &= u_{t+1} + e_{t+1} \\ &= \mathbb{1}^\top x_{t+1} \\ &= \mathbb{1}^\top A x_t \\ &= (1 + b - d) (u_t + e_t) \\ &= (1 + b - d) n_t. \end{aligned}nt+1​​=ut+1​+et+1​=1⊤xt+1​=1⊤Axt​=(1+b−d)(ut​+et​)=(1+b−d)nt​.​
(3)

Hence, the growth rate of ntn_tnt​ is fixed at 1+b−d1 + b - d1+b−d.

Moreover, the times series of unemployment and employment seems to grow at some stable rates in the long run.

33.3.2The application of Perron-Frobenius theorem¶

Since by intuition if we consider unemployment pool and employment pool as a closed system, the growth should be similar to the labor force.

We next ask whether the long-run growth rates of ete_tet​ and utu_tut​ also dominated by 1+b−d1+b-d1+b−d as labor force.

The answer will be clearer if we appeal to Perron-Frobenius theorem.

The importance of the Perron-Frobenius theorem stems from the fact that firstly in the real world most matrices we encounter are nonnegative matrices.

Secondly, many important models are simply linear iterative models that begin with an initial condition x0x_0x0​ and then evolve recursively by the rule xt+1=Axtx_{t+1} = Ax_txt+1​=Axt​ or in short xt=Atx0x_t = A^tx_0xt​=Atx0​.

This theorem helps characterise the dominant eigenvalue r(A)r(A)r(A) which determines the behavior of this iterative process.

33.3.2.1Dominant eigenvector¶

We now illustrate the power of the Perron-Frobenius theorem by showing how it helps us to analyze the lake model.

Since AAA is a nonnegative and irreducible matrix, the Perron-Frobenius theorem implies that:

  • the spectral radius r(A)r(A)r(A) is an eigenvalue of AAA, where

r(A):=max⁡{∣λ∣:λ is an eigenvalue of A}r(A) := \max\{|\lambda|: \lambda \text{ is an eigenvalue of } A \}r(A):=max{∣λ∣:λ is an eigenvalue of A}
(4)

  • any other eigenvalue λ\lambdaλ in absolute value is strictly smaller than r(A)r(A)r(A): ∣λ∣<r(A)|\lambda|< r(A)∣λ∣<r(A),

  • there exist unique and everywhere positive right eigenvector ϕ\phiϕ (column vector) and left eigenvector ψ\psiψ (row vector):

Aϕ=r(A)ϕ,ψA=r(A)ψA \phi = r(A) \phi, \quad \psi A = r(A) \psiAϕ=r(A)ϕ,ψA=r(A)ψ
(5)

  • if further AAA is positive, then with <ψ,ϕ>=ψϕ=1<\psi, \phi> = \psi \phi=1<ψ,ϕ>=ψϕ=1 we have

r(A)−tAt→ϕψr(A)^{-t} A^t \to \phi \psir(A)−tAt→ϕψ
(6)

The last statement implies that the magnitude of AtA^tAt is identical to the magnitude of r(A)tr(A)^tr(A)t in the long run, where r(A)r(A)r(A) can be considered as the dominant eigenvalue in this lecture.

Therefore, the magnitude xt=Atx0x_t = A^t x_0xt​=Atx0​ is also dominated by r(A)tr(A)^tr(A)t in the long run.

Recall that the spectral radius is bounded by column sums: for A≥0A \geq 0A≥0, we have

min⁡jcolsumj(A)≤r(A)≤max⁡jcolsumj(A)\min_j \text{colsum}_j (A) \leq r(A) \leq \max_j \text{colsum}_j (A)jmin​colsumj​(A)≤r(A)≤jmax​colsumj​(A)
(7)

Note that colsumj(A)=1+b−d\text{colsum}_j(A) = 1 + b - dcolsumj​(A)=1+b−d for j=1,2j=1,2j=1,2 and by (7) we can thus conclude that the dominant eigenvalue is r(A)=1+b−dr(A) = 1 + b - dr(A)=1+b−d.

Denote g=b−dg = b - dg=b−d as the overall growth rate of the total labor force, so that r(A)=1+gr(A) = 1 + gr(A)=1+g.

The Perron-Frobenius implies that there is a unique positive eigenvector xˉ=[uˉeˉ]\bar{x} = \begin{bmatrix} \bar{u} \\ \bar{e} \end{bmatrix}xˉ=[uˉeˉ​] such that Axˉ=r(A)xˉA\bar{x} = r(A)\bar{x}Axˉ=r(A)xˉ and [11]xˉ=1\begin{bmatrix} 1 & 1 \end{bmatrix} \bar{x} = 1[1​1​]xˉ=1:

uˉ=b+α(1−d)b+(α+λ)(1−d)eˉ=λ(1−d)b+(α+λ)(1−d)\begin{aligned} \bar{u} & = \frac{b + \alpha (1-d)}{b + (\alpha+\lambda)(1-d)} \\ \bar{e} & = \frac{\lambda(1-d)}{b + (\alpha+\lambda)(1-d)} \end{aligned}uˉeˉ​=b+(α+λ)(1−d)b+α(1−d)​=b+(α+λ)(1−d)λ(1−d)​​
(8)

Since xˉ\bar{x}xˉ is the eigenvector corresponding to the dominant eigenvalue r(A)r(A)r(A), we call xˉ\bar{x}xˉ the dominant eigenvector.

This dominant eigenvector plays an important role in determining long-run outcomes as illustrated below.

def plot_time_paths(lm, x0=None, T=1000, ax=None):
        """
        Plots the simulated time series.

        Parameters
        ----------
        lm : class
            Lake Model
        x0 : array
            Contains some different initial values.
        T : int
            Number of periods to simulate

        """


        if x0 is None:
            x0 = np.array([[5.0, 0.1]])

        ū, ē = lm.ū, lm.ē

        x0 = np.atleast_2d(x0)

        if ax is None:
            fig, ax = plt.subplots(figsize=(10, 8))
            # Plot line D
            s = 10
            ax.plot([0, s * ū], [0, s * ē], "k--", lw=1, label='set $D$')

        # Set the axes through the origin
        for spine in ["left", "bottom"]:
            ax.spines[spine].set_position("zero")
        for spine in ["right", "top"]:
            ax.spines[spine].set_color("none")

        ax.set_xlim(-2, 6)
        ax.set_ylim(-2, 6)
        ax.set_xlabel("unemployed workforce")
        ax.set_ylabel("employed workforce")
        ax.set_xticks((0, 6))
        ax.set_yticks((0, 6))




        # Plot time series
        for x in x0:
            x_ts = lm.simulate_path(x0=x)

            ax.scatter(x_ts[0, :], x_ts[1, :], s=4,)

            u0, e0 = x
            ax.plot([u0], [e0], "ko", ms=2, alpha=0.6)
            ax.annotate(f'$x_0 = ({u0},{e0})$',
                        xy=(u0, e0),
                        xycoords="data",
                        xytext=(0, 20),
                        textcoords="offset points",
                        arrowprops=dict(arrowstyle = "->"))

        ax.plot([ū], [ē], "ko", ms=4, alpha=0.6)
        ax.annotate(r'$\bar{x}$',
                xy=(ū, ē),
                xycoords="data",
                xytext=(20, -20),
                textcoords="offset points",
                arrowprops=dict(arrowstyle = "->"))

        if ax is None:
            plt.show()
lm = LakeModel(α=0.01, λ=0.1, d=0.02, b=0.025)
x0 = ((5.0, 0.1), (0.1, 4.0), (2.0, 1.0))
plot_time_paths(lm, x0=x0)

Since xˉ\bar{x}xˉ is an eigenvector corresponding to the eigenvalue r(A)r(A)r(A), all the vectors in the set D:={x∈R2:x=αxˉ  for some  α>0}D := \{ x \in \mathbb{R}^2 : x = \alpha \bar{x} \; \text{for some} \; \alpha >0 \}D:={x∈R2:x=αxˉfor someα>0} are also eigenvectors corresponding to r(A)r(A)r(A).

This set DDD is represented by a dashed line in the above figure.

The graph illustrates that for two distinct initial conditions x0x_0x0​ the sequences of iterates (Atx0)t≥0(A^t x_0)_{t \geq 0}(Atx0​)t≥0​ move towards DDD over time.

This suggests that all such sequences share strong similarities in the long run, determined by the dominant eigenvector xˉ\bar{x}xˉ.

33.3.2.2Negative growth rate¶

In the example illustrated above we considered parameters such that overall growth rate of the labor force g>0g>0g>0.

Suppose now we are faced with a situation where the g<0g<0g<0, i.e., negative growth in the labor force.

This means that b−d<0b-d<0b−d<0, i.e., workers exit the market faster than they enter.

What would the behavior of the iterative sequence xt+1=Axtx_{t+1} = Ax_txt+1​=Axt​ be now?

This is visualised below.

lm = LakeModel(α=0.01, λ=0.1, d=0.025, b=0.02)
plot_time_paths(lm, x0=x0)

Thus, while the sequence of iterates still moves towards the dominant eigenvector xˉ\bar{x}xˉ, in this case they converge to the origin.

This is a result of the fact that r(A)<1r(A)<1r(A)<1, which ensures that the iterative sequence (Atx0)t≥0(A^t x_0)_{t \geq 0}(Atx0​)t≥0​ will converge to some point, in this case to (0,0)(0,0)(0,0).

This leads us to the next result.

33.3.3Properties¶

Since the column sums of AAA are r(A)=1r(A)=1r(A)=1, the left eigenvector is 1⊤=[1,1]\mathbb{1}^\top=[1, 1]1⊤=[1,1].

Perron-Frobenius theory implies that

r(A)−tAt≈xˉ1⊤=[uˉuˉeˉeˉ].r(A)^{-t} A^{t} \approx \bar{x} \mathbb{1}^\top = \begin{bmatrix} \bar{u} & \bar{u} \\ \bar{e} & \bar{e} \end{bmatrix}.r(A)−tAt≈xˉ1⊤=[uˉeˉ​uˉeˉ​].
(9)

As a result, for any x0=(u0,e0)⊤x_0 = (u_0, e_0)^\topx0​=(u0​,e0​)⊤, we have

xt=Atx0≈r(A)t[uˉuˉeˉeˉ][u0e0]=(1+g)t(u0+e0)[uˉeˉ]=(1+g)tn0xˉ=ntxˉ.\begin{aligned} x_t = A^t x_0 &\approx r(A)^t \begin{bmatrix} \bar{u} & \bar{u} \\ \bar{e} & \bar{e} \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix}u_0 \\ e_0 \end{bmatrix} \\ &= (1+g)^t(u_0 + e_0) \begin{bmatrix}\bar{u} \\ \bar{e} \end{bmatrix} \\ &= (1 + g)^t n_0 \bar{x} \\ &= n_t \bar{x}. \end{aligned}xt​=Atx0​​≈r(A)t[uˉeˉ​uˉeˉ​][u0​e0​​]=(1+g)t(u0​+e0​)[uˉeˉ​]=(1+g)tn0​xˉ=nt​xˉ.​
(10)

as ttt is large enough.

We see that the growth of utu_tut​ and ete_tet​ also dominated by r(A)=1+gr(A) = 1+gr(A)=1+g in the long run: xtx_txt​ grows along DDD as r(A)>1r(A) > 1r(A)>1 and converges to (0,0)(0, 0)(0,0) as r(A)<1r(A) < 1r(A)<1.

Moreover, the long-run unemployment and employment are steady fractions of ntn_tnt​.

The latter implies that uˉ\bar{u}uˉ and eˉ\bar{e}eˉ are long-run unemployment rate and employment rate, respectively.

In detail, we have the unemployment rates and employment rates: xt/nt=Atn0/nt→xˉx_t / n_t = A^t n_0 / n_t \to \bar{x}xt​/nt​=Atn0​/nt​→xˉ as t→∞t \to \inftyt→∞.

To illustrate the dynamics of the rates, let A^:=A/(1+g)\hat{A} := A / (1+g)A^:=A/(1+g) be the transition matrix of rt:=xt/ntr_t := x_t/ n_trt​:=xt​/nt​.

The dynamics of the rates follow

rt+1=xt+1nt+1=xt+1(1+g)nt=Axt(1+g)nt=A^xtnt=A^rt.r_{t+1} = \frac{x_{t+1}}{n_{t+1}} = \frac{x_{t+1}}{(1+g) n_{t}} = \frac{A x_t}{(1+g)n_t} = \hat{A} \frac{x_t}{n_t} =\hat{A} r_t.rt+1​=nt+1​xt+1​​=(1+g)nt​xt+1​​=(1+g)nt​Axt​​=A^nt​xt​​=A^rt​.
(11)

Observe that the column sums of A^\hat{A}A^ are all one so that r(A^)=1r(\hat{A})=1r(A^)=1.

One can check that xˉ\bar{x}xˉ is also the right eigenvector of A^\hat{A}A^ corresponding to r(A^)r(\hat{A})r(A^) that xˉ=A^xˉ\bar{x} = \hat{A} \bar{x}xˉ=A^xˉ.

Moreover, A^tr0→xˉ\hat{A}^t r_0 \to \bar{x}A^tr0​→xˉ as t→∞t \to \inftyt→∞ for any r0=x0/n0r_0 = x_0 / n_0r0​=x0​/n0​, since the above discussion implies

rt=A^tr0=(1+g)−tAtr0=r(A)−tAtr0→[uˉuˉeˉeˉ]r0=[uˉeˉ].r_t = \hat{A}^t r_0 = (1+g)^{-t} A^t r_0 = r(A)^{-t} A^t r_0 \to \begin{bmatrix} \bar{u} & \bar{u} \\ \bar{e} & \bar{e} \end{bmatrix} r_0 = \begin{bmatrix} \bar{u} \\ \bar{e} \end{bmatrix}.rt​=A^tr0​=(1+g)−tAtr0​=r(A)−tAtr0​→[uˉeˉ​uˉeˉ​]r0​=[uˉeˉ​].
(12)

This is illustrated below.

lm = LakeModel()
e_0 = 0.92          # Initial employment
u_0 = 1 - e_0       # Initial unemployment, given initial n_0 = 1

lm = LakeModel()
T = 100         # Simulation length

x_0 = (u_0, e_0)

x_path = lm.simulate_path(x_0, T)

rate_path = x_path / x_path.sum(0)

fig, axes = plt.subplots(2, 1, figsize=(10, 8))

# Plot steady ū and ē
axes[0].hlines(lm.ū, 0, T, 'r', '--', lw=2, label='ū')
axes[1].hlines(lm.ē, 0, T, 'r', '--', lw=2, label='ē')

titles = ['Unemployment rate', 'Employment rate']
locations = ['lower right', 'upper right']

# Plot unemployment rate and employment rate
for i, ax in enumerate(axes):
    ax.plot(rate_path[i, :], lw=2, alpha=0.6)
    ax.set_title(titles[i])
    ax.grid()
    ax.legend(loc=locations[i])


plt.tight_layout()
plt.show()

To provide more intuition for convergence, we further explain the convergence below without the Perron-Frobenius theorem.

Suppose that A^=PDP−1\hat{A} = P D P^{-1}A^=PDP−1 is diagonalizable, where P=[v1,v2]P = [v_1, v_2]P=[v1​,v2​] consists of eigenvectors v1v_1v1​ and v2v_2v2​ of A^\hat{A}A^ corresponding to eigenvalues γ1\gamma_1γ1​ and γ2\gamma_2γ2​ respectively, and D=diag(γ1,γ2)D = \text{diag}(\gamma_1, \gamma_2)D=diag(γ1​,γ2​).

Let γ1=r(A^)=1\gamma_1 = r(\hat{A})=1γ1​=r(A^)=1 and ∣γ2∣<γ1|\gamma_2| < \gamma_1∣γ2​∣<γ1​, so that the spectral radius is a dominant eigenvalue.

The dynamics of the rates follow rt+1=A^rtr_{t+1} = \hat{A} r_trt+1​=A^rt​, where r0r_0r0​ is a probability vector: ∑jr0,j=1\sum_j r_{0,j}=1∑j​r0,j​=1.

Consider zt=P−1rtz_t = P^{-1} r_t zt​=P−1rt​.

Then, we have zt+1=P−1rt+1=P−1A^rt=P−1A^Pzt=Dztz_{t+1} = P^{-1} r_{t+1} = P^{-1} \hat{A} r_t = P^{-1} \hat{A} P z_t = D z_tzt+1​=P−1rt+1​=P−1A^rt​=P−1A^Pzt​=Dzt​.

Hence, we obtain zt=Dtz0z_t = D^t z_0zt​=Dtz0​, and for some z0=(c1,c2)⊤z_0 = (c_1, c_2)^\topz0​=(c1​,c2​)⊤ we have

rt=Pzt=[v1v2][γ1t00γ2t][c1c2]=c1γ1tv1+c2γ2tv2.r_t = P z_t = \begin{bmatrix} v_1 & v_2 \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} \gamma_1^t & 0 \\ 0 & \gamma_2^t \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} c_1 \\ c_2 \end{bmatrix} = c_1 \gamma_1^t v_1 + c_2 \gamma_2^t v_2.rt​=Pzt​=[v1​​v2​​][γ1t​0​0γ2t​​][c1​c2​​]=c1​γ1t​v1​+c2​γ2t​v2​.
(13)

Since ∣γ2∣<∣γ1∣=1|\gamma_2| < |\gamma_1|=1∣γ2​∣<∣γ1​∣=1, the second term in the right hand side converges to zero.

Therefore, the convergence follows rt→c1v1r_t \to c_1 v_1rt​→c1​v1​.

Since the column sums of A^\hat{A}A^ are one and r0r_0r0​ is a probability vector, rtr_trt​ must be a probability vector.

In this case, c1v1c_1 v_1c1​v1​ must be a normalized eigenvector, so c1v1=xˉc_1 v_1 = \bar{x}c1​v1​=xˉ and then rt→xˉr_t \to \bar{x}rt​→xˉ.

33.4Exercise¶

Exercise 1 (Evolution of unemployment and employment rate)

How do the long-run unemployment rate and employment rate evolve if there is an increase in the separation rate α\alphaα or a decrease in job finding rate λ\lambdaλ?

Is the result compatible with your intuition?

Plot the graph to illustrate how the line D:={x∈R2:x=αxˉ  for some  α>0}D := \{ x \in \mathbb{R}^2 : x = \alpha \bar{x} \; \text{for some} \; \alpha >0 \}D:={x∈R2:x=αxˉfor someα>0} shifts in the unemployment-employment space.

Solution to Exercise 1

Eq. (8) implies that the long-run unemployment rate will increase, and the employment rate will decrease if α\alphaα increases or λ\lambdaλ decreases.

Suppose first that α=0.01,λ=0.1,d=0.02,b=0.025\alpha=0.01, \lambda=0.1, d=0.02, b=0.025α=0.01,λ=0.1,d=0.02,b=0.025. Assume that α\alphaα increases to 0.04.

The below graph illustrates that the line DDD shifts clockwise downward, which indicates that the fraction of unemployment rises as the separation rate increases.

fig, ax = plt.subplots(figsize=(10, 8))

lm = LakeModel(α=0.01, λ=0.1, d=0.02, b=0.025)
plot_time_paths(lm, ax=ax)
s=10
ax.plot([0, s * lm.ū], [0, s * lm.ē], "k--", lw=1, label='set $D$, α=0.01')

lm = LakeModel(α=0.04, λ=0.1, d=0.02, b=0.025)
plot_time_paths(lm, ax=ax)
ax.plot([0, s * lm.ū], [0, s * lm.ē], "r--", lw=1, label='set $D$, α=0.04')

ax.legend(loc='best')
plt.show()
